title: Start with memory: Pinecone
body:
### Background #####################################################################

AutoGPT has not been able to start with vectors with Pinecone as a memory backend, but I may have solved this with a 4-file-change. 

### Changes ########################################################################
    
    modified:   autogpt/agent/agent.py
    modified:   autogpt/memory/pinecone.py
    modified:   autogpt/memory/base.py
    modified:   autogpt/memory/init.py

 base.py:
        Added save_vec_num and load_vec_num functions: line 10, 15
 pinecone.py:
        from-import load_vec_num, save_vec_num, clean_input: line 6, 7
        Added self.vec_num = load_vec_num(): line 20
        Added block to check index fullness percentage, prompt to clear: line 45
        Added save_vec_num(self.vec_num) after self.vec_num += 1: line 74
 agent.py:
        Added check for 100% index fullness before adding memory: line 242
 memory.init.py:
        Removed if init, memory.clear statement: line 50

### Documentation ####################################################################
        
        Changes are documented in the code with hash symbols

### Test Plan #########################################################################

        I tested my changes on both the master branch and stable-0.2.2 branch with successful results. However I will note that when AutoGPT creates an index for the first time it raises a service exception(503 error) and disconnects the pinecone API. But once you exit the program and restart, the 'auto-gpt' index is already created so it runs flawlessly. I plan on investigating this further tomorrow.
